reporting-org.narrative: UTZ - joined forces with Rainforest Alliance

title.narrative: Building capacities for sector change: country program Malawi

description.narrative: In 2020 we will have strengthened the lobby and advocacy capacity of civil society organizations in Malawi on living wage, farmer group strengthening and, climate and water. As a result, we will see an improvement of policy environment (both government and companies) and support services in these countries related to these themes. These themes are: 1. Smallholder inclusion & farmer group strengthening The aim is to increase the inclusion of smallholders in supply-chain driven sustainability programs. Strengthening farmer organizations is seen as an important way to increase the bargaining power of smallholder farmers in the supply chain. 2. Women’s empowerment and gender The goal is to increase the inclusion of women in certification and access to benefits as well as to reduce discrimination and violence against women. 3. Climate and water The focus is on up scaling of best practices in smallholder adaptation to climate change and sustainable water use. 4. Living wage The goal is to improve wages of workers on coffee and tea estates towards a living wage.
SP-MAL Building capacities for sector change: country program Malawi

title.narrative: DD5 # of CSOs with increased capacities

description.narrative: CSOs have increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative: tbu

29-04-2019: PAWU has reported increased capacity (also evidenced in the mid-term review). CEPA and PDO also reported increased capacities when we redid the capacity assessment. The 4 trusts + NSTGA also have started increasing their capacities via training received through capacity building project

29-04-2020: 1) NSTGA 2) 2 Local Committees (Agric, VNRMCS) developed engagement skills to engage local leaders around formulation of by-laws in December 2018 in Mulanje and Tyjolo 3) Male and female lead farmers in 2 communities (Mulanje and Tyolo) have increased capacity in lobbying & Advocacy, Gap, NRSM & ALT livelihoods
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.
29-04-2020: PAWU, CEPA, PDO, 4 tea smallholder trusts, NSTGA, 2 smallholder communities, 2 local committees in Mulanje and Tyjolo

29-04-2021: PAWU, NSTGA, Sukambizi trust, Msumadzi trust, Chizunga Trust, Thuchira Trust 1. PAWU was much stronger in pushing for the negotiation with TAML 2. CBA engagement process improved as both TAML and PAWU had clearer expectations and focused on the common goal 3. TAML and PAWU were equal partners at the negotiation table 4. Shop stewards display more knowledge on Functioning and importance of the union - being approached by those in workplace with grievances and know where to take the issues when they are raised 5. More workers understand the role of the union 6. Negotiating for PPE led to appreciation of the role of union in negotiating for their interest amongst union members 6. Union reps & management in the workplace are collaborating on communication and information to workers 7. Sukambizi Trust joined the NSTGA 8. NSTGA was invited to attend the elections of the Trusts to oversee and make sure they are free and fair 9. Msuwadzi trust Reviewed their constitution and comitted to making it a public documents to all trust members and blocks 10. Chizunga Trust reviewed their constitution and comitted to making it a public document to all trust members and blocks 11. Sukambizi Trust Updated their constitution and comitted to maing it a public document to all trust members and blocks 12. Thuchira Trust Committed to review certain provisions of their constitution and committed to make it a public dokument to all trust members and blocks 13. NSTGA & Trusts reports an increase in knowledge, understanding and skills internalised on leadership, financial management, constitutional development, lobby and advocacy. 14. Chizunga, Msuwadzi trusts got an established office. 15. Chizunga, Msuwadzi leadership changed during elections.

title.narrative: Country Scan

description.narrative: During the first part of the inception phase of the program (December 2015-March 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff, carried out a deeper analysis of the sector(s) and themes proposed for their countries to develop a more focused approach for the SP program. The objective of the Country Scans was “to provide a situational analysis on each sector and theme per country assessing the current state with regards to the relevant thematic SP objectives, clearly formulating the causes of the problem that need addressing and identify opportunities for interventions and provide recommendations on potential partners for these interventions.” The Country Scan documents are based on our own experience in the countries, but also document review, conversations/interviews with experts, key informants including Dutch embassy staff, national and international organizations, and workshop results with many of these actors.

title.narrative: # of country scans

comment.narrative: 1 country scan is completed for Malawi
10-01-2018: 1 country scan completed for Malawi

title.narrative: Country Plan

description.narrative: During the second part of the inception phase of the program (April-July 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff in drafting the country plans. The purpose of the SP country program plan is to set out a strategic direction for sector change in the country and serves as a framework. This plan clearly states UTZ goals for the country the Theory of Change to guide interventions as well as the budget for said activities. Overall, the SP Country Plan will serve as a guide for the next years, as well as a basis for the year plans that will be formulated for 2017 to 2020.

title.narrative: # of country plans

comment.narrative: 1 country plan is completed for Malawi
10-01-2018: 1 country plan is completed for Malawi

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 1: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers

description.narrative: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers in policy/law-making processes

title.narrative: DD3 # of more inclusive policy/law-making processes

description.narrative: Voices, needs and interests of male and female farmers, smallholders and workers are better included in the development of policies and services

comment.narrative: 04-06-2019: 1. In the clmate change project- in Thyolo and Mulanje communittees: there is particpation of female farmers in CC risk assessment, Inclusion of women in Lead Farmer committees and increased communication between smallholders and local government 2. Smallholder trust: leadership engages with their members to get better insight in their needs & established a gender committee 3. Trusts and NSTGA more inclusive governance: leadership Coming together to discuss and review constitution and adopting the changes including a commitment by Trusts to amend their constitutions to suit the interests of smallholder farmers, M/F 4. Wage negotiation process: TAML & PAWU: TAML increased engagement with PAWU, more recognition, clearer expectations, common focus, Improved communication

29-04-2020: 1) women participate in Annual General Meeting of Msuwauzi Trust 2)Election of women in leadership position in Sukambizi trust (Swamion 3)NSTGA (national smallholder tea growers association) is providing mediation of farmer issues and needs 4) Sukambizi trust showed an interest to also work with NSTGA - this will give the trusts the possibility to speak with one voice 5) NSTGA leadership identified and raised issues affecting farmers with TAML 6)all trusts have changed internally their behavior towards women where women have taken up leadership roles of 50% at board level. 7) Communitees in Mulanje and Thyolo implement gender equal practices such as shared resource control at house hold level; Shared responsibilities and roles at hh level; Appointment of women in leadership positions 8) LW: TAML is willing to be part of the verification process to validate the membership threshold for PAWU.

29-04-2021: 1. Ability and confidence to report issues of sexual harassment - there has been an increase in reporting (evidence is available- cases are captured) by women workers. Women in the room have confirmed that cases are being reported. So many cases coming up as women are reporting. Lujeri - new case of manager requesting sexual favours from women. Some cases reported by women - all the estates have these issues and women know who to approach and openly doing so. 2. Women represented in Block Committees during routine elections of new office bearers 3. Women represented in Trust Committees during routine elections of new office bearers (note: there was a call for early elections given the urgency that women should be included in Trust Committees) 4. Chisunga trust: Vice Chairperson is a woman for the first time 5. Tuchira trust: Secretary, Vice Chairperson, administrator are all women 6. NSTGA: Gender was included as a key consideration in the constitution to ensure there is a balance in the executive 7. Gender was also included as a key consideration in the constitution of the trusts to ensure there is a balance in the executive 8. Improved representation and protection of worker rights: 8.1. Shop stewards display more knowledge on Functioning and importance of the union - being approached by those in workplace with grievances and know where to take the issues when they are raised 8.2. More workers understand the role of the union. Negotiating for PPE led to appreciation of the role of union in negotiating for their interest amongst union members 8.3. Union reps & management in the workplace are collaborating on communication and information to workers

title.narrative: Pathway 2: Research and pilots to create evidence for L&A

description.narrative: New knowledge & evidence is generated & widely accepted/ endorsed by key stakeholders

title.narrative: # of POs/CSOs/unions that use the evidence from research products to advocate for improved services or wages

comment.narrative: tbu

29-04-2019: 1. The climate change maps have been used repeatedly. They were used at the Dubai global tea forum and will also be used at the GLF conference in August. This material as been invaluable in being able to show the threat of CC to the Malawi tea sector. We are also highlighting the landscapes project at the GLF to lobby for further funding to upscale this work for the Mulanje Mountain. 2. The union PAWU however has been able to use the research from the Anker report done last year through the wages committee to provide evidence for the re-negotiated CBA
29-04-2020: Chizunga Trust is using its database to make informed decisions on critical issues such as children education, gender, access to water and sanitation facilities
29-04-2021: PAWU, NSTGA

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Ankers LW report.; climate change maps
29-04-2020: 1) smallholder information system for Chizunga Trust 2)material for 10 videos collected by sunshine cinema and they are being edited

title.narrative: Pathway 2: Research and pilots to create evidence for L&A

description.narrative: Activities to create new knowledge/evidence are implemented

comment.narrative: 10-01-2018: Including: - Climate change impacts on tea production in Malawi [Theme: Climate change] - Malawi 2020 - Wage Committee Support [Theme: Living wage]
these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines
24-04-2018: Nursery study, pilot for smallholder information system, project to develop an Environmental Smallholder Management Plan

29-04-2021: Establishment of Beekeeping clubs in Mpando and Zimbo Blocks: To establish 100 hives in within the duration of the project and train a core contingent of 82 local community members up to Intermediate Stage in the practice of bee-farming. This microeconomic enterprise will be based on a Producer Organisation mechanism supporting a number of Bee Clubs comprising upwards of 3 hives per person.(consultant, Chisomo Bee Products)
these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 3: Improvement of services

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; increased funding for services

title.narrative: DD1 # of new or improved government/company programs & services with budget allocation that are targeted and tailored to the needs of female and male smallholders and workers (related to the theme)

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests; increased funding for services

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: 1) Government extension workers inThyolo and Mulanje find increased demand from farmers and respond by providing support services. Previously, the smallholders relied on the extension support from estates (outgrower managers) and Government extension services purely focused on the Tea Estates. 2) Makante Estate established a smallholder Trust office which strengthens the commitment and organisation capacity of the smallholders and improves service delivery to trust / members
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

title.narrative: Baseline Report

description.narrative: The baseline provides an elaborate context-analysis per country, containing details about capacity of partners and the current state regarding the thematic goals for L&A. The baseline focuses on three main areas: a. Description of baseline situation of context and stakeholders b. Baseline of outcomes of ToC c. Capacities assessment

title.narrative: # of baseline reports

comment.narrative: 1 baseline report is completed for Malawi

29-04-2020: 1)RA has been drafted into the leadership team of the big landscape program led by IDH. 2) SP implementing partner (CEPA) is part of the IDH landscape program so that they can share their experience from the pilot program and help design the sector-wide program

comment.narrative: 29-04-2020: 1)the African Investment Bank had RA speaking about investment in the agriculture sector to address climate change; attended by the Minister of Finance 2)the Ministry of Labour had RA talking about the role of certification in addressing gender inequality, attended by the Commissioner for Labour 3) We were also invited to talk about what certification could do to address child labour in commodities that are predominantly traded locally
